subTitleBlogPost: Sharing My Journey in Code, Design, and Discovery

blogCards.title: Warp - the only terminal I ever need
blogCards.content:
I've been using Warp for a while now, and I must say, it's the only terminal I ever need. It initially launched for Mac, and I discovered it when I had issues with my built-in terminal and was searching for a new one. That's when I found Warp.
At the time, it was only available on Mac, and I’d been checking for updates on Windows every now and then. A few weeks ago, it finally came to Windows, and I was thrilled. The installation process was incredibly easy on both Mac and Windows. While it offers various themes and customizable text options, the absolute best part is that I can now save my terminal commands. I have many commands in my head, but not all of them, and some I don't use frequently. For example, when I need to change a commit message. Sure, Google can help, but now I can save those commands and access them with just one click whenever I need them. Another amazing feature is the built-in AI, which lets me write and ask for specific commands, even explaining what the command does. Another thing I love is that I don’t need to use the arrow keys to navigate—I can simply use my mouse. If I notice a typo, I can click on it and make changes directly. It's just so much easier.
I absolutely love it. It’s a must-have for any developer who appreciates the power of the terminal like I do.

blogCards.title: Printagon Order Form
blogCards.content: Right now, I am working on a new Printagon order form. I had a meeting with a client to discuss their needs before I implemented the function. Which fields should be required. After the meeting, I started working on the form. Now, I'm working on the backend API, which will be finished soon before I move on to the frontend and create the reusable input form with input fields and a text area.
